author: Joe Romm
title: Trump to abandon millions of high-wage jobs to China
text:
Beijing will create 13 million jobs by 2020, investing $360 billion in clean energy, while Trump vows to abandon the sector. Renewable energy jobs in select countries (excluding large hydropower). CREDIT: IRENA China is preparing to go big on the only major new source of sustainable high-wage employment in the coming decades.
In its newest 5-year energy development plan, Beijing plans to invest a stunning 2.5 trillion yuan ($360 billion) in renewable power generation by 2020. Of that, $144 billion will go to solar, about $100 billion to wind, $70 billion to hydropower, and the rest to sources like tidal and geothermal power.
The Chinese National Energy Administration (NEA) said in a statement Thursday the resulting “employment will be more than 13 million people.”
China is already doing way better than the United States in this regard, and President-elect Trump’s commitment to opposing clean energy will not make things any better.
As the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) reported last year , China already has over 40 percent of all jobs in renewables, globally, while the U.S. has under 10 percent (see chart above).
We know that clean energy jobs are the only major new source of sustainable high-wage employment in the coming decades for several reasons.
Clean energy will be a $50-trillion industry, but Trump policies mean the U.S. won’t benefit 
First, the rapid price drops in the core technologies have made clean energy a juggernaut . Second, the nations of the world unanimously committed in Paris to do what it takes to avoid catastrophic warming. That means running the entire world on carbon-free power by the century’s end.
A recent Duke University study found there needs to be a “tenfold jump” in clean energy technologies in order to meet global emissions targets. That is a $50 trillion (or more ) commitment in the coming decades. Therefore we are talking tens of millions of new jobs, something no other emerging sector can match .
No wonder China decided to be the leader in both manufacturing and deployment of solar and wind power. And no wonder they have made an equally large bet on batteries and electric vehicles (EVs), which is how they blew past both the United States and Europe in total sales back in 2015.
CREDIT: Argonne National Laboratory (via Wikipedia) China more than doubled electric car sales in 2016, and the Chinese government is aiming at a more than 1,000 percent increase in sales by 2025 — some 3 million new EVs a year. To achieve that, “ it’s offering subsidies that can total 60 percent of an electric-car’s sticker price,” Bloomberg News reported.
Third, the fossil fuel industry simply has no sustainable growth model. Advanced batteries could “tip the oil market from growth to contraction earlier than anticipated,” credit rating agency Fitch concluded last year . Bloomberg New Energy Finance had already told investors to expect the “big crash” in oil by 2028 — and as early as 2023.
And despite the fact that President-elect Trump has promised to bring back coal jobs, that goal is quite simply beyond his power , even if he succeeds in temporarily stopping the explosive growth of clean energy.
The “real war” on coal workers was waged “by the coal industry itself,” Nobel prize-winning economist Paul Krugman explained in 2014 . “Strip mines and machinery in general have allowed us to produce more coal with very few miners.”
Wikipedia Even Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) conceded after the election that it’s unlikely that substantial coal jobs will be coming back.
Nonetheless, while China understands there is a relatively short window of time to achieve global leadership in the core carbon-free technologies, Trump promised to kill U.S. and global climate action while zeroing out federal clean energy funding .
So while Trump might have extended a temporary lifeline to the dirty fuels of the past, millions and millions of the jobs of the future will apparently be captured by more forward-looking countries… like China.
Trump to abandon millions of high-wage jobs to China was originally published in ThinkProgress on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
